Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Opportunities for STEM Achievement (OSA) program at Mercy College, a federally-designated Hispanic Serving Institution, will award scholarships of $4,000 to incoming freshmen and transfer students and scholarships of up to $6,000 per year to continuing students pursuing degrees in: Computer Information Systems, Computer Science, Cybersecurity, and Mathematics. OSA will serve a population of academically talented, financially needy students who are often first-generation and largely underrepresented in these fields. The goal of the program will be to assure that at least 85 percent of OSA scholars graduate in in four or five years. The OSA program will result in an increase of the number of individuals prepared for entry into the STEM workforce and able to pursue graduate education in STEM disciplines.

The OSA program will build on the successes of three former NSF grants. OSA scholars will receive personalized advisement along with an Individual Achievement Plan designed to improve persistence; faculty-mentored research and opportunities to present at conferences; seminars and career exploration presented by external professionals; traditional support services including professional and peer tutoring to increase academic achievement; and assistance with career preparation for immediate entry in STEM employment or admission to graduate school. Annual assessments, facilitated by an external evaluator, will measure scholar graduation rates and will also inform changes that may need to be made in OSA's design during implementation. Lessons learned and effective practices that emerge from the program evaluation data will be disseminated to the STEM education community and help enlarge the knowledge base regarding attributes and practices of successful scholarship programs of this type.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes Report     

 

Since its founding in 1950, Mercy College has been committed to providing students the opportunity to transform their lives through liberal arts, sciences, and professional education in personalized learning environments.  Today the College is a comprehensive, independent, federally-designated Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) serving 7,993 degree-seeking undergraduate and 2,564 graduate students.  Through its NSF S-STEM grant, Opportunities for STEM Achievement (OSA), awarded in 2015, Mercy College offered scholarships and support services to academically talented, financially needy undergraduates enrolled in the Mathematics and Computer Sciences Department at Mercy College. Four academic majors leading to a Bachelor of Science degree were included: Computer Information Systems (CIS); Computer Science (CS); Mathematics; and Cybersecurity (CSEC) (dual degree program BS + MS).  

 

Many students of Mercy College are from economically disadvantaged backgrounds and are the first in their families to attend college. Students from low-income or first-generation college backgrounds often lack role models in math, science, and engineering, preventing them from understanding the pathway needed for careers in these fields. This project enabled students underrepresented in the computer information sciences and math fields to receive scholarships of up to $6000 per year, along with a variety of support services, and professional development activities. These program components assisted students to complete degree programs, thereby helping to address the growing need for STEM professionals.  

 

The retention rate in STEM majors for S-STEM program participants was 93.3%, which exceeded our goal of 85%. Of the total 60 S-STEM participants, 45 graduated with a Bachelor?s degree in one of the STEM fields and had cumulative undergraduate GPAs at the time of graduation of 3.56. Thirty-seven out of these 45 NSF scholars (82.2%) were accepted to graduate programs in STEM or are now working in STEM fields. For example, one NSF scholar received a dual degree (4+1 BS+MS) in Cybersecurity with Distinction and is working full time as a Data Security Administration Associate at Lockheed Martin. Another NSF scholar graduated with a Bachelor of Science in Computer Science degree (Magna Cum Laude) and is working full time as a Product Integration Engineer at Bridgewater Associates.

 

Project faculty mentored NSF scholars as they worked on research projects on various topics, such as applications of Graph Theory to Chemistry, applications of Number Theory to Cryptosystems, configuration of secure network infrastructure, and laser communications. NSF scholars participated in various Cyber Skill Competitions such as the Hackathon tournament in the northeast region, the National Cyber League, and the fifth Cyber Skill Competition sponsored by Mercy College and the National Security Agency. Moreover, in spring 2018, the Mercy College team ranked high (fourth place among 84 teams in the Bronze Bracket) at a National Cyber League competition. In fall 2018 and spring 2019, NSF scholars ranked top in Infrastructure Defense at the Hackathon tournament, third in the Gold bracket, and first in the Silver bracket of the National Cyber League. Moreover, NSF scholars presented their research projects at various conferences such as the Westchester Undergraduate Research Conference and annual meetings of the Metropolitan New York section of the Mathematical Association of America.

 

  Some of the many professional development events for students in MATH/CS programs included presentations by alumni about their experiences pursuing graduate degrees or working in STEM fields; panel discussions by cybersecurity professionals about various topics such as data privacy and job opportunities; and presentations from the Director and Co-director of Mercy College?s Center for Academic Excellence and Innovation (CAEI).

 

Scholars traveled to professional meetings/conferences, which offered hands-on learning experiences, presentations from leading experts, and networking opportunities. These opportunities gave participants vital educational experiences, including meeting with experts in STEM fields and peers from other institutions.  With the support of OSA, faculty and NSF scholars in the department of MATH/CS had opportunities to attend various conferences in their fields, such as the 27th joint National Conference of National Association of African American Studies (NAAAS) & Affiliates; the 48th Southeastern International Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory, and Computing; the QCon/ai symposium; the Rose-Hulman Undergraduate Math Conference; the SIGCSE 2019 Technical Symposium; the ASU-GSV Summit; and the Math and Magic workshop at the National Museum of Mathematics.
